that's us heartland alliance for human

by a quick show of hands before tonight

there's the problem right that is the

they're doing all of these amazing

we're going to tell you a little bit
about that effort and to start I think
it's a little helpful actually to start

like a Heartland history lesson a
chicago history lesson and really
because heartland was established back
in the
late 1800s so in 1888 and we were
established as the nation's second
travelers and immigrants aid
organization so you see people nodding
kind of recognized that name and really
we were founded out of the settlement
house movement so if you remember back
you might have gone in a field trip to
the hull house if you grew up here over
on Halsted you know Jane Addams founded
the hull house and was the leader of the
settlement house movement she was one of
our founders at heartland alliance as
well now we've grown a lot over the 20th
century that's for sure we've changed a
lot interesting fact that we still run
our travelers aid program if you've been
at O'Hare Airport and you see those
information kiosks that's heartland's
travelers aid program so that's our
legacy program so if you need assistance
at the airport we are there still
shepherding travelers and immigrants and

transportation and more broadly the city
so I you know I was in Barcelona last
year patricio is going there next month
so I started to think that in many
respects heartland is a little bit like
Audi sagrada familia we have been under
construction for 100 years for a century
we are we still have cranes up we are
constantly adding we are constantly
refining we are adding detail we're

constant under construction entity and
this is not entirely not not at all
unique to Heartland a lot of people in
this a lot of organizations in the
social service structure are kind of
this exact same way and some really good
examples of how we've been of how we've
done this over the years you know we
were kind of the first organization in
Chicago to respond to the homeless
crisis in the 80s when that became kind
of a prevailing and very recognizable
social problem we founded this help fund
the Chicago Coalition for the homeless
which you might be familiar with we were
the first place in the city to open up a
homeless youth shelter when we realized
that the face of homelessness was
changing
and that it wasn't the single man on the
street that everybody might have thought
it was we led the effort to relocate
evacuees to Chicago we put 27,000 people
back to work through the country's
largest jobs program during the
recession we were the first responders
in the city to the AIDS HIV AIDS crisis
so as social problems have evolved in
emerge so too has heartland so too has
the rest of our kind of social service
industry but if I'm really honest I
think it's a little bit grandiose to
compare Heartland to a beautiful
well-planned and thought out cathedral
